natural problem: A standard deck of 52 cards has 13 ranks (Ace, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King) and 4 suits ($\spadesuit$, $\heartsuit$, $\diamondsuit$, and $\clubsuit$), such that there is exactly one card for any given rank and suit.  Two of the suits ($\spadesuit$ and $\clubsuit$) are black and the other two suits ($\heartsuit$ and $\diamondsuit$) are red.  The deck is randomly arranged. What is the probability that the top three cards are all $\spadesuit$s?
natural solution: There are 13 ways to choose the first card to be a $\spadesuit$, then 12 ways to choose the second card to be another $\spadesuit$, then 11 ways to choose the third card to be a $\spadesuit$. There are $52 \times 51 \times 50$ ways to choose any three cards.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda>n. n / 52)"
and h1 : "probability 13 * probability 12 * probability 11 = 11 / 850"
shows  "probability 3 = 11 / 850"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard deck of 52 cards has 13 ranks (Ace, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King) and 4 suits ($\spadesuit$, $\heartsuit$, $\diamondsuit$, and $\clubsuit$), such that there is exactly one card for any given rank and suit.  Two of the suits ($\spadesuit$ and $\clubsuit$) are black and the other two suits ($\heartsuit$ and $\diamondsuit$) are red.  The deck is randomly arranged. What is the probability that the top three cards are all $\spadesuit$s? The final Answer is \dfrac{11}{850}
 ### Proof
 There are 13 ways to choose the first card to be a $\spadesuit$, then 12 ways to choose the second card to be another $\spadesuit$, then 11 ways to choose the third card to be a $\spadesuit$. There are $52 \times 51 \times 50$ ways to choose any three cards.
 So the probability is $\dfrac{13 \times 12 \times 11}{52 \times 51 \times 50} = \boxed{\dfrac{11}{850}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda>n. n / 52)"
and h1 : "probability 13 * probability 12 * probability 11 = 11 / 850"
shows  "probability 3 = 11 / 850"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Suppose the probability of an event occurring is given by the formula $\frac{n}{52}$. If the probability of three events occurring consecutively is given by the product of their individual probabilities: $\frac{13}{52} \cdot \frac{12}{52} \cdot \frac{11}{52} = \frac{11}{850}$, find the probability of the third event, which is given by $\frac{3}{52}$. The final answer is $\frac{11}{850}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cards spades :: nat
assumes h0 : "cards = 52"
and h1 : "spades = 13"
shows  "3 * spades div cards = 11 div 850"

(* ### Problem

 So the probability is $\dfrac{13 \times 12 \times 11}{52 \times 51 \times 50} = \boxed{\dfrac{11}{850}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes cards spades :: nat
assumes h0 : "cards = 52"
and h1 : "spades = 13"
shows  "3 * spades div cards = 11 div 850"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a standard deck of 52 playing cards, there are 13 spades. What is the value of $\frac{3 \times 13}{52}$? Express your answer as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{11}{850}$.

fixes deck :: "nat"

fixes prob :: "real"

assumes h0 : "P = (card {x. x in spades}) / (card {x. x in deck})"

shows  "P * (12 / 51) * (11 / 50) = 11 / 850"

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (card {x :: card. suit x = spade}) / (card {x :: card. suit x \<in> {spade, heart, diamond, club}})"
and h1 : "P = (card {x :: card. suit x = spade} - 1) / (card {x :: card. suit x \<in> {spade, heart, diamond, club}} - 1)"
and h2 : "P = (card {x :: card. suit x = spade} - 2) / (card {x :: card. suit x \<in> {spade, heart, diamond, club}} - 2)"
and h3 : "card {x :: card. suit x = spade} = 13"
and h4 : "card {x :: card. suit x \<in> {spade, heart, diamond, club}} = 52"
shows  "P = 11 / 850"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard deck of 52 cards has 13 ranks (Ace, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King) and 4 suits ($\spadesuit$, $\heartsuit$, $\diamondsuit$, and $\clubsuit$), such that there is exactly one card for any given rank and suit.  Two of the suits ($\spadesuit$ and $\clubsuit$) are black and the other two suits ($\heartsuit$ and $\diamondsuit$) are red.  The deck is randomly arranged. What is the probability that the top three cards are all $\spadesuit$s? The final Answer is \dfrac{11}{850}
 ### Proof
 There are 13 ways to choose the first card to be a $\spadesuit$, then 12 ways to choose the second card to be another $\spadesuit$, then 11 ways to choose the third card to be a $\spadesuit$. There are $52 \times 51 \times 50$ ways to choose any three cards.
 So the probability is $\dfrac{13 \times 12 \times 11}{52 \times 51 \times 50} = \boxed{\dfrac{11}{850}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (card {x :: card. suit x = spade}) / (card {x :: card. suit x \<in> {spade, heart, diamond, club}})"
and h1 : "P = (card {x :: card. suit x = spade} - 1) / (card {x :: card. suit x \<in> {spade, heart, diamond, club}} - 1)"
and h2 : "P = (card {x :: card. suit x = spade} - 2) / (card {x :: card. suit x \<in> {spade, heart, diamond, club}} - 2)"
and h3 : "card {x :: card. suit x = spade} = 13"
and h4 : "card {x :: card. suit x \<in> {spade, heart, diamond, club}} = 52"
shows  "P = 11 / 850"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a standard deck of 52 playing cards, with 13 cards of each suit (spades, hearts, diamonds, and clubs), find the probability that if you draw three cards without replacement, all three of them will be spades. The final answer is $\frac{11}{850}$.
